data.title: Fanfare of Love (1935)
data.meta_description: Two unemployed musicians dress up as women to be hired by an all -female orchestra "Tulips from Holland"; they fall in love with two gorgeous musicians.
data.text:
Billy Wilder's Some Like It Hot was based on a 1951 German film. But that film was a remake of an earlier 1935 French comedy. This is the original about two down-on-their-luck musicians dressing up as women to play in an all-girl band - the Tulips of Holland. It doesn't have Wilder's script or Marilyn. But it's still quite delightful, and the musical numbers aren't bad either.

Jean (Fernand Gravey) and Pierre (Julien Carette) are a funny duo - with mismatched height like Mutt and Jeff. Carette in particular has great comic timing. They become Jeanette and Pierette. There's a lot that's familiar with the later film - the sleeper car sequence, criss-crossed love interests with men pursuing them as…

This film was billed, and introduced, as an early version of Some Like it Hot, albeit one separated by the latter film by a 1951 German remake. That comparison doesn't help this movie. This movie too often goes for the obvious joke, while it lacks the sense of danger and locomotive momentum Wilder puts on screen. The film does work well as a musical. The scene on the train where the two male musicians in disguise meet their female colleagues is stunning, the camera moves along the train car in an impressive tracking shot. The music is good, its signature song is a nice tune which helps because it uses it a lot. A final positive is Betty Stockfield who…

A direct inspiration for Billy Wilder’s 1959 American sensation, Some Like It Hot, Fanfare d’amour is a cinematic treat of romantic comedy, musical numbers, and a first-rate cast.

Fanfare d’amour follows Jean Rameau (Fernand Gravey) and Pierre Dupont (Julien Carette), two out-of-work musicians in search of stable employment who eventually set their sights on the female-led Tulips orchestra when they learn of two openings in the group. Jean and Pierre disguise themselves as women to audition, ultimately landing the job and joining the group as they travel, rehearse, and perform together, facing unexpected twists and turns along the way.

The film was restored in 4K from the original 35mm nitrate fine grain and a vintage 35mm print, which is the…
